entry.title: How to Create and Deploy a Preact Application on Hostman
entry.summary: Preact is a popular choice for building lightweight, high-performance web applications, especially when developers want a React-like experience with a smaller footprint. In this article, we will discuss a quick way to deploy a Preact application and run it in the cloud environment. We will go step by step through all the stages, from the initial project setup to cloud deployment. https://hostman.com/tutorials/how-to-create-and-deploy-a-preact-application-on-hostman-app-platform/ What we will cover: Preact vs React Setting Up the Development Environment Installing Node.js and npm Quick Start with Vite (optional but convenient) Manual Setup (Alternative Option) Deployment with Hostman App Platform Expanding Preact Functionality Working with Routing and State Preact Signals: An Alternative Approach to State Optimizing and Speeding Up Preact Application Load Code Splitting and Lazy Loading in Preact Additional Tips Possible Errors When Migrating from Preact to React

entry.title: Terraform AWS multi-region deployments: region meta-argument in Beta
entry.summary: Terraform holds a solid position in the ADOPT category of SOK Tech Radar, and for a good reason. Most our teams rely on it to define and provision cloud infrastructure across AWS, Azure, and other platforms. One of the Terraform‚Äôs biggest strengths lies in its modular architecture, which allows teams to use and share best practices through reusable modules. Another reason to love Terraform? The frequent updates to HCL that often make me go ‚Äúwooh‚Äù! This post dives into one such update ‚Äî still in beta but offering a much cleaner approach to multi-region deployments. Managing AWS resources across multiple regions has traditionally required separate provider configurations for each of the regions. If you‚Äôve ever needed to deploy something like an SNS topic in multiple regions, you probably kno‚Ä¶

entry.title: üß† Deep Dive into Solana‚Äôs Account Model: The Backbone of Solana‚Äôs Architecture
entry.summary: ‚úçÔ∏è Written for developers, students, and anyone getting started with Solana who want to truly understand how data lives and moves on the network. When working with Solana, understanding how accounts function is absolutely critical. Unlike traditional databases or even other blockchains, Solana structures nearly everything through its unique Account Model. This article will walk you through the concept of Solana accounts, what they store, how they operate, and why they are fundamental to everything built on the platform. On Solana, everything is an account. Literally. Whether it's a user‚Äôs wallet, a smart contract, a token mint, or program data ‚Äî all are stored in accounts. Think of Solana as a massive public key-value store where each key is a unique address (public key), and the value is ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Implementing Domain-Driven Design with C# and Entity Framework
entry.summary:
Implementing Domain-Driven Design with C# and Entity Framework
When building complex software systems, it can be tempting to jump straight into coding without a clear understanding of the problem domain. This often leads to brittle, hard-to-maintain codebases that fail to meet the needs of the business. Enter Domain-Driven Design (DDD)‚Äîa methodology that emphasizes collaboration between technical and business stakeholders to design software that truly reflects the core business domain. In this blog post, we‚Äôll explore how to implement Domain-Driven Design principles in C# using Entity Framework (EF). We‚Äôll cover key concepts like aggregates, repositories, value objects, and domain services, complete with practical code examples. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned developer or new to DDD, this gui‚Ä¶

entry.title: Intersection Observer API
entry.summary:
The Intersection Observer API allows you to configure a callback that is called when either of these circumstances occur: A traget element intersects either the device's viewport or a specified element. That specified element is called the root element or root for the purposes of the Intersection Observer API.
The first time the observer is initially asked to watch a target element.
Typically, you'll want to watch for intersection changes with regard to the target element's closest scrollable ancestor, or, if the target element is not a descendant of a scrollable element, the device's viewport. The API works the same way, in all cases, whether you're using the viewport or some other element as the root. The degree of intersection between the target element and its root is the interse‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is a submission for Frontend Challenge - June Celebrations, CSS Art: June Celebrations.
entry.summary: This is a submission for Frontend Challenge - June Celebrations, CSS Art: June Celebrations. For this challenge, I decided to showcase my personal portfolio ‚Äì a celebration of my skills, growth, and passion as a frontend developer. This project reflects both my technical abilities and design sensibility, presented in a minimalist and professional way. üîó Live Portfolio: rohit.bhatu.in Code: Not open-sourced yet, but feel free to explore the site and connect for collaborations! Building this portfolio was a rewarding process that pushed me to refine my UI/UX decisions and strengthen my frontend skills. I used: React & Next.js for component-driven structure and performance Tailwind CSS for utility-first styling and responsive design Framer Motion for smooth UI interactions What I‚Äôm most proud of is keeping the design clean, functional, and reflective of who I am as a developer. Through this challenge, I also explored fine-tuning layout responsiveness and animation transitions. Looking forward to improving it further by integrating a blog section and some light/dark mode enhancements! Thanks for checking it out! Feedback is always welcome üòä.

entry.title: Explain the concept of garbage collection in Java. How can it be triggered manually?
entry.summary: Garbage collection in Java is the process of automatically identifying and removing unused or unreachable objects from memory to free up resources. It helps in preventing memory leaks and optimizing application performance. Java handles garbage collection through the JVM (Java Virtual Machine), which tracks objects no longer referenced by any part of the program. Although it is automatic, developers can suggest garbage collection by calling System.gc(), but it is not guaranteed to execute immediately. Efficient memory management through garbage collection ensures smooth and stable Java applications.

entry.title: LEDGR - Receipts In, Insights Out. Automatically.
entry.summary: This is a submission for the Postmark Challenge: Inbox Innovators. Let's be honest, 'expense tracking' often sounds like a synonym for 'tedious,' 'boring,' and 'something I'll definitely start next month.' We all know we should keep an eye on our spending, especially with the convenience of online shopping, and how carried away we can get with it. But the reality is, saving digital receipts, painstakingly entering data into a spreadsheet or app, and trying to remember what category 'that random Amazon purchase' falls into is enough to make anyone give up. With the hustle of our everyday lives, tracking online orders is just not something we can prioritise, but it is something we should prioritise because those purchases add up and you can go overboard so easily. Your inbox is a goldmine o‚Ä¶
